{{original research|date=December 2015}} '''Reflective practice''' is the ability to reflect on one's actions so as to engage in a process of continuous learning.<ref name="Schon">{{cite book |last=Sch√∂n |first=Donald A. |authorlink=Donald Sch√∂n |date=1983 |title=The reflective practitioner: how professionals think in action |location=New York |publisher=[[Basic Books]] |isbn=046506874X |oclc=8709452 |ref=harv}}</ref> According to one definition it involves "paying critical attention to the practical values and theories which inform everyday actions, by examining practice reflectively and reflexively. This leads to developmental insight".<ref>{{cite book |last=Bolton |first=Gillie |date=2010 |origyear=2001 |title=Reflective practice: writing and professional development |edition=3rd |location=Los Angeles |publisher=[[Sage Publications]] |isbn=9781848602113 |oclc=458734364 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=XSNiMpiHuwcC&pg=PR19 xix]}}</ref> A key rationale for reflective practice is that experience alone does not necessarily lead to learning; deliberate [[Human self-reflection|reflection]] on experience is essential.<ref name="Loughran">{{cite journal |last=Loughran |first=J. John |date=January 2002 |title=Effective reflective practice: in search of meaning in learning about teaching |journal=Journal of Teacher Education |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=33‚Äì43 |doi=10.1177/0022487102053001004 |url=http://oneteacher.global2.vic.edu.au/files/2014/09/Loughlan-242761j.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cochran-Smith |first1=Marilyn |last2=Lytle |first2=Susan L. |date=January 1999 |title=Relationships of knowledge and practice: teacher learning in communities |journal=Review of Research in Education |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=249‚Äì305 |doi=10.3102/0091732X024001249 |jstor=1167272}}</ref>
Reflective practice can be an important tool in [[practice-based professional learning]] settings where people learn from their own professional experiences, rather than from [[formal learning]] or [[knowledge transfer]]. It may be the most important source of personal [[professional development]] and improvement. It is also an important way to bring together theory and practice; through reflection a person is able to see and label forms of thought and theory within the context of his or her work.<ref>{{cite journal |last=McBrien |first=Barry |date=July 2007 |title=Learning from practice‚Äîreflections on a critical incident |journal=[[Accident and Emergency Nursing]] |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=128‚Äì133 |doi=10.1016/j.aaen.2007.03.004 |pmid=17540574}}</ref> A person who reflects throughout his or her practice is not just looking back on past actions and events, but is taking a conscious look at emotions, experiences, actions, and responses, and using that information to add to his or her existing knowledge base and reach a higher level of understanding.<ref name="paterson-chapman">{{cite journal |last1=Paterson |first1=Colin |last2=Chapman |first2=Judith |date=August 2013 |title=Enhancing skills of critical reflection to evidence learning in professional practice |journal=Physical Therapy in Sport |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=133‚Äì138 |doi=10.1016/j.ptsp.2013.03.004 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Judith_Chapman4/publication/236637498_Enhancing_skills_of_critical_reflection_to_evidence_learning_in_professional_practice/links/540992db0cf2822fb739aff7.pdf |pmid=23643448}}</ref>
==History and background== [[File:Donald schon pic.jpg|thumb|right|Donald Sch√∂n]] [[Donald Sch√∂n]]'s 1983 book ''The Reflective Practitioner'' introduced concepts such as ''reflection-on-action'' and ''reflection-in-action'' which explain how professionals meet the challenges of their work with a kind of [[improvisation]] that is improved through practice.<ref name="Schon"/> However, the concepts underlying reflective practice are much older. Earlier in the 20th century, [[John Dewey]] was among the first to write about reflective practice with his exploration of experience, interaction and reflection.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dewey |first=John |authorlink=John Dewey |date=1998 |origyear=1933 |title=How we think: a restatement of the relation of reflective thinking to the educative process |location=Boston |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin]] |isbn=0395897548 |oclc=38878663}}</ref> Soon thereafter, other researchers such as [[Kurt Lewin]] and [[Jean Piaget]] were developing relevant theories of human learning and development.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Alice Y. |last1=Kolb |first2=David A. |last2=Kolb |authorlink2=David A. Kolb |year=2005 |title=Learning styles and learning spaces: enhancing experiential learning in higher education |journal=[[Academy of Management Learning and Education]] |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=193‚Äì212 |citeseerx=10.1.1.127.6489 |doi=10.5465/AMLE.2005.17268566}}</ref> Some scholars have claimed to find precursors of reflective practice in ancient texts such as [[Buddhist]] teachings<ref>{{cite journal |last=Winter |first=Richard |date=March 2003 |title=Buddhism and action research: towards an appropriate model of inquiry for the caring professions |journal=Educational Action Research |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=141‚Äì160 |doi=10.1080/09650790300200208}}</ref> and the ''[[Meditations]]'' of [[Stoicism|Stoic]] philosopher [[Marcus Aurelius]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Suibhne |first=Seamus Mac |date=September 2009 |title='Wrestle to be the man philosophy wished to make you': Marcus Aurelius, reflective practitioner |journal=Reflective Practice: International and Multidisciplinary Perspectives |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=429‚Äì436 |doi=10.1080/14623940903138266}}</ref>
Central to the development of reflective theory was interest in the integration of theory and practice, the cyclic pattern of experience and the conscious application of lessons learned from experience. Since the 1970s, there has been a growing literature and focus around [[experiential learning]] and the development and application of reflective practice.
As [[adult education]] professor David Boud and his colleagues explained: "Reflection is an important human activity in which people recapture their experience, think about it, mull it over and evaluate it. It is this working with experience that is important in learning."<ref name="Boud">{{cite book |last1=Boud |first1=David |last2=Keogh |first2=Rosemary |last3=Walker |first3=David |date=1985 |title=Reflection, turning experience into learning |location=London; New York |publisher=[[Kogan Page]]; Nichols |isbn=0893972029 |oclc=11030218 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=BGUOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA19 19]}}</ref> When a person is experiencing something, he or she may be [[implicit learning|implicitly learning]]; however, it can be difficult to put emotions, events, and thoughts into a coherent sequence of events. When a person rethinks or retells events, it is possible to categorize events, emotions, ideas, etc., and to compare the intended purpose of a past action with the results of the action. Stepping back from the action permits [[critical reflection]] on a sequence of events.<ref name="paterson-chapman"/>
The emergence in more recent years of [[blogging]] has been seen as another form of reflection on experience in a technological age.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wopereis |first1=Iwan G.J.H. |last2=Sloep |first2=Peter B. |last3=Poortman |first3=Sybilla H. |title=Weblogs as instruments for reflection on action in teacher education |journal=Interactive Learning Environments |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=245‚Äì261 |year=2010 |doi=10.1080/10494820.2010.500530 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Peter_Sloep/publication/220095297_Weblogs_as_instruments_for_reflection_on_action_in_teacher_education/links/02bfe50fd8c738b584000000.pdf}}</ref>
==Models<!--Section linked from [[Learning cycle]]: do not rename without fixing incoming link (see [[MOS:HEAD]])-->== Many models of reflective practice have been created to guide [[reasoning]] about action.
===Borton 1970<!--Section linked from [[Start With Why]]: do not rename without fixing incoming link (see [[MOS:HEAD]])-->=== {{See also|Start With Why#The golden circle}} [[File:Steph Rol Model.jpg|thumb|Terry Borton's reflective model (1970), as adapted by Gary Rolfe and colleagues (2001)]] Terry Borton's 1970 book ''Reach, Touch, and Teach'' popularized a simple [[learning cycle]] inspired by [[Gestalt therapy]] composed of three questions which ask the practitioner: ''What'', ''So what'', and ''Now what''?<ref>{{cite book |last=Borton |first=Terry |date=1970 |title=Reach, touch, and teach: student concerns and process education |location=New York |publisher=[[McGraw-Hill]] |oclc=178000}}</ref> Through this analysis, a description of a situation is given which then leads into the scrutiny of the situation and the construction of knowledge that has been learnt through the experience. Subsequently, practitioners reflect on ways in which they can personally improve and the consequences of their response to the experience. Borton's model was later adapted by practitioners outside the field of education, such as the field of nursing and the helping professions.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Rolfe |first1=Gary |last2=Freshwater |first2=Dawn |last3=Jasper |first3=Melanie |date=2001 |title=Critical reflection for nursing and the helping professions: a user's guide |location=Houndmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire; New York |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan|Palgrave]] |isbn=0333777956 |oclc=46984997 |pages=26‚Äì35}}</ref>
===Kolb and Fry 1975=== [[File:Steph Kol Model.jpg|thumb|Adaptation of Kolb's reflective model]] Learning theorist [[David A. Kolb]] was highly influenced by the earlier research conducted by [[John Dewey]] and [[Jean Piaget]]. Kolb's reflective model highlights the concept of [[experiential learning]] and is centered on the transformation of information into knowledge. This takes place after a situation has occurred, and entails a practitioner reflecting on the experience, gaining a general understanding of the concepts encountered during the experience, and then testing these general understandings in a new situation. In this way, the knowledge that is formed from a situation is continuously applied and reapplied, building on a practitioner's prior experiences and knowledge.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kolb |first1=David A. |authorlink1=David A. Kolb |last2=Fry |first2=Ronald E. |date=1975 |chapter=Towards an applied theory of experiential learning |editor-last=Cooper |editor-first=Cary L. |title=Theories of group processes |series=Wiley series on individuals, groups, and organizations |location=London; New York |publisher=Wiley |pages=33‚Äì58 |isbn=0471171174 |oclc=1103318}}</ref>
===Argyris and Sch√∂n 1978===
[[Management]] researchers [[Chris Argyris]] and [[Donald Sch√∂n]] pioneered the idea of ''single-loop learning'' and ''[[double-loop learning]]'' in 1978. Their theory was built around the recognition and correction of a perceived fault or error.<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Mark K. |year=2013 |origyear=2001 |url=http://www.infed.org/thinkers/argyris.htm |title=Chris Argyris: theories of action, double-loop learning and organizational learning |publisher=The encyclopedia of informal education |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> Single-loop learning is when a practitioner or organisation, even after an error has occurred and a correction is made, continues to rely on current strategies, techniques or policies when a situation again comes to light. Double-loop learning involves the modification of objectives, strategies or policies so that when a similar situation arises a new framing system is employed.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Argyris |first1=Chris |authorlink1=Chris Argyris |last2=Sch√∂n |first2=Donald A. |authorlink2=Donald Sch√∂n |date=1996 |origyear=1978 |title=Organizational learning: a theory of action perspective |series=Addison-Wesley OD series |volume=1 |location=Reading, MA |publisher=[[Addison-Wesley]] |isbn=0201001748 |oclc=503599388}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=November 2010}}
Sch√∂n claimed to derive the notions of "reflection-on-action, reflection-in-action, responding to problematic situations, problem framing, problem solving, and the priority of practical knowledge over abstract theory" from the writings of [[John Dewey]], although education professor Harvey Shapiro has argued that Dewey's writings offer "more expansive, more integrated notions of professional growth" than do Sch√∂n's.<ref name="Shapiro">{{cite journal |last=Shapiro |first=Harvey |date=2010 |title=John Dewey's reception in 'Sch√∂nian' reflective practice |journal=Philosophy of Education Archive |pages=311‚Äì319 [311] |url=http://ojs.ed.uiuc.edu/index.php/pes/article/view/3049}}</ref>
Schon advocated 2 types of reflective practice. Firstly, reflection-on-action, which involves reflecting on an experience that you have already had, or an action that you have already taken, and considering what could have been done differently, as well as looking at the positives from that interaction. The other type of reflection Schon notes is reflection-in-action, or reflecting on your actions as you are doing them, and considering issues like best practice throughout the process.
For Sch√∂n, professional growth really begins when a person starts to view things with a critical lens, by doubting his or her actions. [[Doubt]] brings about a way of thinking that questions and frames situations as "problems". Through careful planning and systematic elimination of other possible problems, doubt is settled, and people are able to affirm their knowledge of the situation. Then people are able to think about possible situations and their outcomes, and deliberate about whether they carried out the right actions.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}
===Gibbs 1988=== [[File:Steph Gib Model.jpg|thumb|Adaptation of the Gibbs reflective model]] Learning researcher Graham Gibbs discussed the use of structured [[debriefing]] to facilitate the reflection involved in Kolb's experiential [[learning cycle]]. Gibbs presents the stages of a full structured debriefing as follows:<ref>{{cite book |last=Gibbs |first=Graham |year=1988 |title=Learning by doing: a guide to teaching and learning methods |location=London |publisher=Further Education Unit |isbn=1853380717 |oclc=19809667 |url=http://www2.glos.ac.uk/gdn/gibbs/ |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> * (Initial experience) * '''Description''' *: "What happened? Don't make judgements yet or try to draw conclusions; simply describe." * '''Feelings''' *: "What were your reactions and feelings? Again don't move on to analysing these yet." * '''Evaluation''' *: "What was good or bad about the experience? Make value judgements." * '''Analysis''' *: "What sense can you make of the situation? Bring in ideas from outside the experience to help you." *: "What was really going on?" *: "Were different people's experiences similar or different in important ways?" * '''Conclusions (general)''' *: "What can be concluded, in a general sense, from these experiences and the analyses you have undertaken?" * '''Conclusions (specific)''' *: "What can be concluded about your own specific, unique, personal situation or way of working?" * '''Personal action plans''' *: "What are you going to do differently in this type of situation next time?" *: "What steps are you going to take on the basis of what you have learnt?"
Gibbs' suggestions are often cited as "Gibbs' reflective cycle" or "Gibbs' model of reflection", and simplified into the following six distinct stages to assist in structuring reflection on learning experiences:<ref>{{cite techreport |last=Finlay |first=Linda |date=January 2008 |title=Reflecting on 'reflective practice' |number=PBPL paper 52 |institution=Practice-based Professional Learning Centre, [[The Open University]] |url=http://www.open.ac.uk/opencetl/sites/www.open.ac.uk.opencetl/files/files/ecms/web-content/Finlay-(2008)-Reflecting-on-reflective-practice-PBPL-paper-52.pdf |page=8}}</ref> * Description * Feelings * Evaluation * Analysis * Conclusions * Action plan
===Johns 1995=== [[File:Steph Joh Model2.jpg|thumb|Adaptation of the Johns reflective model]] Professor of nursing Christopher Johns designed a structured mode of reflection that provides a practitioner with a guide to gain greater understanding of his or her practice.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Johns |first1=Christopher |last2=Burnie |first2=Sally |date=2013 |origyear=2000 |title=Becoming a reflective practitioner |edition=4th |location=Chichester, UK; Ames, Iowa |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell]] |isbn=9780470674260 |oclc=823139850 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LWifyeS9ol0C}}</ref> It is designed to be carried out through the act of sharing with a colleague or mentor, which enables the experience to become learnt knowledge at a faster rate than reflection alone.<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Johns |editor-first=Christopher |date=2010 |origyear=2002 |title=Guided reflection: a narrative approach to advancing professional practice |edition=2nd |location=Chichester, UK; Ames, Iowa |publisher=Blackwell |isbn=9781405185684 |oclc=502392750 |doi=10.1002/9781444324969 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uf-3GyLX1QwC}}</ref>
Johns highlights the importance of experienced knowledge and the ability of a practitioner to access, understand and put into practice information that has been acquired through empirical means. Reflection occurs though "looking in" on one's thoughts and emotions and "looking out" at the situation experienced. Johns draws on the work of Barbara Carper to expand on the notion of "looking out" at a situation.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Barbara A. |last1=Carper |title=Fundamental patterns of knowing in nursing |date=October 1978 |journal=Advances in Nursing Science |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=13‚Äì24 |doi=10.1097/00012272-197810000-00004 |pmid=110216}}</ref> Five [[Carper's fundamental ways of knowing|patterns of knowing]] are incorporated into the guided reflection: the aesthetic, personal, ethical, empirical and reflexive aspects of the situation. Johns' model is comprehensive and allows for reflection that touches on many important elements.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Johns |first1=Christopher |title=Framing learning through reflection within Carper's fundamental ways of knowing in nursing |journal=[[Journal of Advanced Nursing]] |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=226‚Äì234 |date=August 1995 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2648.1995.22020226.x |pmid=7593941}}</ref>
===Brookfield 1998=== [[Adult education]] scholar [[Stephen Brookfield]] proposed that critically reflective practitioners constantly research their assumptions by seeing practice through four complementary lenses: the lens of their autobiography as learners of reflective practice, the lens of other learners' eyes, the lens of colleagues' experiences, and the lens of theoretical, philosophical and research literature.<ref name="Brookfield1998">{{cite journal |last=Brookfield |first=Stephen D. |authorlink=Stephen Brookfield |title=Critically reflective practice |journal=Journal of Continuing Education in the Health Professions |date=Autumn 1998 |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=197‚Äì205 |doi=10.1002/chp.1340180402 |url=http://library.sau.edu/committee/brookfieldCritically.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402093458/http://library.sau.edu/committee/brookfieldCritically.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-04-02 }}</ref> Reviewing practice through these lenses makes us more aware of the power dynamics that infuse all practice settings. It also helps us detect hegemonic assumptions‚Äîassumptions that we think are in our own best interests, but actually work against us in the long run.<ref name="Brookfield1998"/> Brookfield argued that these four lenses will reflect back to us starkly different pictures of who we are and what we do. * ''Lens 1: Our autobiography as a learner''. Our autobiography is an important source of insight into practice. As we talk to each other about critical events in our practice, we start to realize that individual crises are usually collectively experienced dilemmas. Analysing our autobiographies allows us to draw insight and meanings for practice on a deep visceral emotional level. * ''Lens 2: Our learners' eyes''. Seeing ourselves through learners' eyes, we may discover that learners are interpreting our actions in the way that we mean them. But often we are surprised by the diversity of meanings people read into our words and actions. A cardinal principle of seeing ourselves through learners' eyes is that of ensuring the anonymity of their critical opinions. We have to make learners feel safe. Seeing our practice through learners' eyes helps us teach more responsively. * ''Lens 3: Our colleagues' experiences''. Our colleagues serve as critical mirrors reflecting back to us images of our actions. Talking to colleagues about problems and gaining their perspective increases our chance of finding some information that can help our situation. * ''Lens 4: Theoretical literature''. Theory can help us "name" our practice by illuminating the general elements of what we think are idiosyncratic experiences.
==Application== Reflective practice has been described as an unstructured or semi-structured approach directing learning, and a self-regulated process commonly used in health and teaching professions, though applicable to all professions.<ref name="Schon"/><ref name="Boud"/><ref name="Larrivee 2000">{{cite journal |last1=Larrivee |first1=Barbara |title=Transforming teaching practice: becoming the critically reflective teacher |journal=Reflective Practice: International and Multidisciplinary Perspectives |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=293‚Äì307 |year=2000 |doi=10.1080/713693162 |url=http://ed253jcu.pbworks.com/f/Larrivee_B_2000CriticallyReflectiveTeacher.pdf}}</ref> Reflective practice is a learning process taught to professionals from a variety of disciplines, with the aim of enhancing abilities to communicate and making informed and balanced decisions. Professional associations such as the [[American Association of Nurse Practitioners]] are recognizing the importance of reflective practice and require practitioners to prepare reflective portfolios as a requirement to be licensed, and for yearly quality assurance purposes.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}
===Education=== The concept of reflective practice has found wide application in the field of education, for learners, teachers and those who teach teachers. Hadiya Habib(2017) assert that there is one quality above all that makes a good teacher -the ability to reflect on what, why and how we do things and to adopt and develop our practice within lifelong learning. Reflection is the key to successful learning for teachers and for learners.
====Students==== Students can benefit from engaging in reflective practice as it can foster the critical thinking and decision making necessary for continuous learning and improvement.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = The Portfolio Organizer: Succeeding with Portfolios in your Classroom|last = Rolheiser, C. Bower, B. Stevahn, L|first = |publisher = Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.|year = 2000|isbn = |location = Alexandria, VA|pages = }}</ref> When students are engaged in reflection, they are thinking about how their work meets established criteria; they analyze the effectiveness of their efforts, and plan for improvement.<ref name=":0" /> Rolheiser and et al. (2000) assert that "Reflection is linked to elements that are fundamental to meaningful learning and cognitive development: the development of metacognition ‚Äì the capacity for students to improve their ability to think about their thinking; the ability to self-evaluate - the capacity for students to judge the quality of their work based on evidence and explicit criteria for the purpose of doing better work; the development of critical thinking, problem-solving, and decision-making; and the enhancement of teacher understanding of the learner." (p 31-32)
When teachers teach metacognitive skills, it promotes student self-monitoring and self-regulation that can lead to intellectual growth, increase academic achievement, and support transfer of skills so that students are able to use any strategy at any time and for any purpose.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.edugains.ca/resourcesCurrImpl/Secondary/FSL/SupplementaryMaterials/ConnectingPracticeandResearchMetacognitionGuide.pdf|title = Connecting Practice and Research: Metacognition Guide|date = 2008|accessdate = |website = Connecting Practice and Research: Metacognition Guide|publisher = Queens Printer|last = Ontario Ministry of Education|first = }}</ref> Guiding students in the habits of reflection requires teachers to approach their role as that of "facilitator of [[meaning-making]]" ‚Äì they organize instruction and classroom practice so that students are the producers, not just the consumers, of knowledge.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Learning and leading with habits of mind: 16 essential characteristics for success.|last = Costa, A., Kallick, B.|first = |publisher = Association for supervision and Curriculum Development|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Alexandria, VA|pages = }}</ref> Rolheiser and colleagues (2000) state that "When students develop their capacity to understand their own thinking processes, they are better equipped to employ the necessary cognitive skills to complete a task or achieve a goal. Students who have acquired metacognitive skills are better able to compensate for both low ability and insufficient information." (p. 34)
The Ontario Ministry of Education (2007)<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.edu.gov.on.ca/eng/literacynumeracy/inspire/research/studentselfassessment.pdf|title = Capacity Building Series: Student Self Assessment|date = 2007|accessdate = |website = Literacy and Numeracy Secretariat Capacity Building Series|publisher = Queens Printer|last = Ontario Ministry of Education|first = }}</ref> describes many ways in which educators can help students acquire the skills required for effective reflection and self-assessment, including: modelling and/or intentionally teaching critical thinking skills necessary for reflection and self-assessment practices; addressing students' perceptions of self-assessment; engaging in discussion and dialogue about why self-assessment is important; allowing time to learn self-assessment and reflection skills; providing many opportunities to practice different aspects of the self-assessment and reflection process; and ensuring that parents/guardians understand that self-assessment is only one of a variety of assessment strategies that is utilized for student learning.
====Teachers==== The concept of reflective practice is now widely employed in the field of teacher education and teacher professional development and many programmes of initial teacher education claim to espouse it.<ref name="Loughran"/> In education, a minimalist understanding of reflective practice is that it refers to the process of the educator studying his or her own teaching methods and determining what works best for the students and the consideration of the ethical consequences of classroom procedures on students; a broader understanding would accept that it also involves questioning the organisational, social and political context in which the teaching takes place.<ref name="Larrivee 2000"/> Education professor Hope Hartman has described reflective practice in education as teacher [[metacognition]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Hartman |first=Hope J. |date=2001 |chapter=Teaching metacognitively |editor-last=Hartman |editor-first=Hope J. |title=Metacognition in learning and instruction: theory, research, and practice |series=Neuropsychology and cognition |volume=19 |location=Dordrecht; Boston |publisher=[[Kluwer Academic Publishers]] |pages=149‚Äì172 |isbn=079236838X |oclc=45655382 |doi=10.1007/978-94-017-2243-8_8}}</ref>
There is broad consensus that teaching effectively requires a reflective approach.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hatton |first1=Neville |last2=Smith |first2=David |date=January 1995 |title=Reflection in teacher education: towards definition and implementation |journal=Teaching and Teacher Education |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=33‚Äì49 |doi=10.1016/0742-051X(94)00012-U}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Cochran-Smith |first=Marilyn |date=January 2003 |title=Learning and unlearning: the education of teacher educators |journal=Teaching and Teacher Education |volume=19 |issue=1 |pages=5‚Äì28 |doi=10.1016/S0742-051X(02)00091-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jones |first1=Jennifer L. |last2=Jones |first2=Karrie A. |date=January 2013 |title=Teaching reflective practice: implementation in the teacher-education setting |journal=The Teacher Educator |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=73‚Äì85 |doi=10.1080/08878730.2012.740153 |url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/08878730.2012.740153 |ref=harv}}</ref> However, reflective practice "is a term that carries diverse meaning"<ref name="Loughran"/> and about which there is not complete consensus.<ref name="Leitch 2000">{{cite journal |last1=Leitch |first1=Ruth |last2=Day |first2=Christopher |date=March 2000 |title=Action research and reflective practice: towards a holistic view |journal=Educational Action Research |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=179‚Äì193 |doi=10.1080/09650790000200108 |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/09650790000200108}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Davey |first1=Ronnie |last2=Ham |first2=Vince |date=March 2010 |title='It's all about paying attention!' ‚Ä¶ but to what? The '6 Ms' of mentoring the professional learning of teacher educators |journal=Professional Development in Education |volume=36 |issue=1‚Äì2 |pages=229‚Äì244 |doi=10.1080/19415250903457158}}</ref> Teaching and learning are complex processes, and there is not one right approach. Reflecting on different approaches to teaching, and reshaping the understanding of past and current experiences, can lead to improvement in teaching practices.<ref name="Leitch 2000"/> Sch√∂n's reflection-in-action can help teachers explicitly incorporate into their decision-making the professional knowledge that they gain from their experience in the classroom.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fien |first1=John |last2=Rawling |first2=Richard |title=Reflective practice: a case study of professional development for environmental education |journal=The Journal of Environmental Education |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=11‚Äì20 |date=April 1996 |doi=10.1080/00958964.1996.9941462}}</ref>
As professor of education Barbara Larrivee argues, reflective practice moves teachers from their knowledge base of distinct skills to a stage in their careers where they are able to modify their skills to suit specific contexts and situations, and eventually to invent new strategies.<ref name="Larrivee 2000"/> In implementing a process of reflective practice teachers will be able to move themselves, and their schools, beyond existing theories in practice.<ref name="Leitch 2000"/> Larrivee concludes that teachers should "resist establishing a classroom culture of control and become a reflective practitioner, continuously engaging in a critical reflection, consequently remaining fluid in the dynamic environment of the classroom".<ref name="Larrivee 2000"/>
[[Video]] recordings of classroom activities have been used to help trainee teachers / education interns develop more detailed reflective practice.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rosaen |first1=Cheryl L. |last2=Lundeberg |first2=Mary |last3=Cooper |first3=Marjorie |last4=Fritzen |first4=Anny |last5=Terpstra |first5=Marjorie |date=September 2008 |title=Noticing noticing: how does investigation of video records change how teachers reflect on their experiences? |journal=[[Journal of Teacher Education]] |volume=59 |issue=4 |pages=347‚Äì360 |doi=10.1177/0022487108322128 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Cheryl_Rosaen/publication/230853172_Noticing_Noticing/links/0deec53c9731066097000000.pdf}}</ref>
According to physiotherapists Colin Paterson and Judith Chapman, reflection or learning from experience is key to staying accountable, and maintaining and developing aptitude throughout a teacher's practice.<ref name="paterson-chapman"/> Without reflection, teachers are not able to look objectively at their actions or take into account the emotions, experience, or consequences of actions to improve their practice. It is argued that, through the process of reflection, teachers are held accountable to the standards of practice for teaching, such as those in [[Ontario]]: commitment to students and student learning, professional knowledge, professional practice, leadership in learning communities, and ongoing [[Professional learning community|professional learning]].<ref name="Ontario">{{cite web |title=Standards of practice |publisher=[[Ontario College of Teachers]] |url=http://www.oct.ca/public/professional-standards/standards-of-practice |accessdate=10 March 2015}}</ref> Through reflective practice, teachers look back on their practice and reflect on how they have supported students by treating them "equitably and with respect and are sensitive to factors that influence individual student learning".<ref name="Ontario"/> By doing this, teachers ask themselves: "Have I to the best of my abilities supported student learning, and provided all of my students with an entry point into learning?" Through reflection, and sharing their reflection, teachers show strong leadership because they show that they are willing to learn from their mistakes and improve their practice for everyone affected by it.<ref name="Ontario"/>
====Teacher educators==== {{Citation style|date=January 2017|details=References in this section should be converted to citation templates to follow the same citation style as the rest of article, per [[WP:CITEVAR]]|section}} For students to acquire necessary skills in reflection, their teachers need to be able to teach and model reflective practice (see above); similarly, teachers themselves need to have been taught reflective practice during their initial teacher education, and to continue to develop their reflective skills throughout their career.
However, Mary Ryan has noted that students are often asked to "reflect" without being taught how to do so,<ref name="Ryan">Ryan, M. (2013) 'The pedagogical balancing act: teaching reflection in higher education', Teaching in Higher Education, 18:2, pp 144-155</ref> or without being taught that different types of reflection are possible; they may not even receive a clear definition or rationale for reflective practice.<ref name="Hebert">H√©bert, C. (2015) 'Knowing and/or experiencing: a critical examination of the reflective models of John Dewey and Donald Sch√∂n', Reflective Practice: International and Multidisciplinary Perspectives</ref> Many new teachers do not know how to transfer the reflection strategies they learned in college to their classroom teaching.<ref name="Jones">Jones, J.L. and Jones, K.A. (2013): 'Teaching Reflective Practice: Implementation in the Teacher-Education Setting'; The Teacher Educator, 48 p.1, 73-85)</ref>
Some writers have advocated that reflective practice needs to be taught explicitly to student teachers because it is not an intuitive act;<ref name="Will">Williams, R. and Grudnoff, L. (2011) "Making sense of reflection: a comparison of beginning and experienced teachers' perceptions of reflection for practice". Reflective practice: international and multidisciplinary perspectives, 9, 177-184</ref><ref name="Ryan" /> it is not enough for teacher educators to provide student teachers with "opportunities" to reflect: they must explicitly "teach reflection and types of reflection" and "need explicitly to facilitate the process of reflection and make transparent the metacognitive process it entails".<ref name="Nagle">Nagle JF (2008), 'Becoming a Reflective Practitioner in the Age of Accountability', The Educational Forum, 73 p.1, 76-86</ref> Larrivee notes that (student) teachers require "carefully constructed guidance" and "multifaceted and strategically constructed interventions" if they are to reflect effectively on their practice.<ref name="Larrivee 2000"/>
Rod Lane and colleageues list strategies by which teacher educators can promote a habit of reflective practice in pre-service teachers, such as discussions of a teaching situation, reflective interviews or essays about one's teaching experiences, action research, or journaling or blogging.<ref name="Lane">Lane, R., McMaster, H., Adnum J., and Cavanagh, M. (2014) 'Quality reflective practice in teacher education: a journey towards shared understanding,' Reflective Practice: International and Multidisciplinary Perspectives, 15 p.4, 481-494 [282]</ref>
Neville Hatton and David Smith, in a brief literature review, conclude that teacher education programmes do use a wide range of strategies with the aim of encouraging students teachers to reflect (e.g. action research, case studies, video-recording or supervised practicum experiences), but that "there is little research evidence to show that this [aim] is actually being achieved".<ref name="Hatton">Hatton N and Smith D (1995), 'Reflection in Teacher Education: towards definition and implementation', Teaching & Teacher Education, Vol. 11, No. 1, pp. 33-49 [36]</ref>
The implication of all this is that teacher educators must also be highly skilled in reflective practice. Andrea Gelfuso and Danielle Dennis, in a report on a formative experiment with student teachers, suggest that teaching how to reflect requires teacher educators to possess and deploy specific competences.<ref name="Gelfuso">{{cite journal | author = Gelfuso A., Dennis D. | year = 2014 | title = Getting reflection off the page: the challenges of developing support structures for pre-service teacher reflection | url = | journal = Teaching and Teacher Education | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 1‚Äì11 | doi=10.1016/j.tate.2013.10.012}}</ref> However, Janet Dyment and Timothy O'Connell, in a small-scale study of experienced teacher educators, noted that the teacher educators they studied had received no training in using reflection themselves, and that they in turn did not give such training to their students; all parties were expected to know how to reflect.<ref name="Dyment">{{cite journal | author = Dyment J.E., O'Connell T.S. | year = 2014 | title = When the Ink Runs Dry: Implications for Theory and Practice When Educators Stop Keeping Reflective Journals | url = | journal = Innovation in HE | volume = 39 | issue = | pages = 417‚Äì429 | doi=10.1007/s10755-014-9291-6}}</ref>
Many writers advocate for teacher educators themselves to act as models of reflective practice.<ref name="Lough">{{cite journal | author = Loughran J., Berry A. | year = 2005 | title = Modelling by teacher educators | url = | journal = Teaching and Teacher Education | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 193‚Äì203 | doi=10.1016/j.tate.2004.12.005}}</ref><ref name="Russ">{{cite journal | author = Russell T | year = 2013 | title = Has Reflective Practice Done More Harm than Good in Teacher Education? | url = | journal = Phronesis | volume = 2 | issue = 1| pages = 80‚Äì88 | doi=10.7202/1015641ar}}</ref> This implies that the way that teacher educators teach their students needs to be congruent with the approaches they expect their students to adopt with pupils; teacher educators should not only model the way to teach, but should also explain why they have chosen a particular approach whilst doing so, by reference to theory; this implies that teacher educators need to be aware of their own tacit theories of teaching and able to connect them overtly to public theory.<ref name="swennen">{{cite journal | author = Swennen A., Lunenberg M., Korthagen F. | year = 2008 | title = Preach what you teach! Teacher educators and congruent teaching | url = | journal = Teachers and Teaching: theory and practice | volume = 14 | issue = 5| pages = 531‚Äì542 | doi=10.1080/13540600802571387}}</ref> However, some teacher educators do not always "teach as they preach";<ref name="Lunenberg">{{cite journal | author = Lunenberg M., Korthagen F.A.J. | year = 2003 | title = Teacher educators and student-directed learning | url = | journal = Teaching and Teacher Education | volume = 19 | issue = | pages = 29‚Äì44 | doi=10.1016/s0742-051x(02)00092-6}}</ref> they base their teaching decisions on "common sense" more than on public theory<ref name="Lunen2">{{cite journal | author = Lunenberg M., Korthagen F., Swennen A. | year = 2007 | title = The teacher educator as a role model | url = | journal = Teaching and Teacher Education | volume = 23 | issue = | pages = 586‚Äì601 | doi=10.1016/j.tate.2006.11.001}}</ref> and struggle with modelling reflective practice.<ref name="Lough"/>
Tom Russell, in a reflective article looking back on 35 years as teacher educator, concurs that teacher educators rarely model reflective practice, fail to link reflection clearly and directly to professional learning, and rarely explain what they mean by reflection, with the result that student teachers may complete their initial teacher education with "a muddled and negative view of what reflection is and how it might contribute to their professional learning".<ref name="Russell">Russell, T. (2013) 'Has Reflective Practice Done More Harm than Good in Teacher Education?' Phronesis, 2(1), pp. 80-88</ref> For Russell, these problems result from the fact that teacher educators have not sufficiently explored how theories of reflective practice relate to their own teaching, and so have not made the necessary "paradigmatic changes" which they expect their students to make.<ref name="Russell"/>
===Health professionals=== Reflective practice is viewed as an important strategy for health professionals who embrace lifelong learning. Due to the ever-changing context of healthcare and the continual growth of medical knowledge, there is a high level of demand on healthcare professionals' expertise. Due to this complex and continually changing environment, healthcare professionals could benefit from a program of reflective practice.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hendricks |first1=Joyce |last2=Mooney |first2=Deborah |last3=Berry |first3=Catherine |date=April 1996 |title=A practical strategy approach to use of reflective practice in critical care nursing |journal=Intensive and Critical Care Nursing |volume=12 |issue=2 |pages=97‚Äì101 |doi=10.1016/S0964-3397(96)81042-1 |pmid=8845631}}</ref>
Adrienne Price explained that there are several reasons why a healthcare practitioner would engage in reflective practice: to further understand one's motives, perceptions, attitudes, values, and feelings associated with client care; to provide a fresh outlook to practice situations and to challenge existing thoughts, feelings, and actions; and to explore how the practice situation may be approached differently.<ref name="Price 2004">{{cite journal |last=Price |first=Adrienne |date=August 2004 |title=Encouraging reflection and critical thinking in practice |journal=Nursing Standard |volume=18 |issue=47 |pages=46‚Äì52 |doi=10.7748/ns2004.08.18.47.46.c3664}}</ref> In the field of nursing there is concern that actions may run the risk of habitualisation, thus dehumanising patients and their needs.<ref name="Walker1996">{{cite journal |last1=Walker |first1=Susan |title=Reflective practice in the accident and emergency setting |journal=[[Accident and Emergency Nursing]] |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=27‚Äì30 |date=January 1996 |doi=10.1016/S0965-2302(96)90034-X |pmid=8696852}}</ref> In using reflective practice, nurses are able to plan their actions and consciously monitor the action to ensure it is beneficial to their patient.<ref name="Walker1996"/>
The act of reflection is seen as a way of promoting the development of autonomous, qualified and self-directed professionals, as well as a way of developing more effective healthcare teams.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ghaye |first=Tony |date=2005 |title=Developing the reflective healthcare team |location=Oxford; Malden, MA |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell|Blackwell]] |isbn=1405105917 |oclc=58478682 |doi=10.1002/9780470774694}}</ref> Engaging in reflective practice is associated with improved quality of care, stimulating personal and professional growth and closing the gap between theory and practice.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jasper |first=Melanie |date=2013 |origyear=2003 |title=Beginning reflective practice |series=Nursing and health care practice series |edition=2nd |location=Andover |publisher=[[Cengage Learning]] |isbn=9781408075265 |oclc=823552537}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=November 2010}} Medical practitioners can combine reflective practice with [[checklist]]s (when appropriate) to reduce diagnostic error.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Graber |first1=Mark L. |last2=Kissam |first2=Stephanie |last3=Payne |first3=Velma L. |last4=Meyer |first4=Ashley N. D. |last5=Sorensen |first5=Asta |last6=Lenfestey |first6=Nancy |last7=Tant |first7=Elizabeth |last8=Henriksen |first8=Kerm |last9=LaBresh |first9=Kenneth |last10=Singh |first10=Hardeep |date=July 2012 |title=Cognitive interventions to reduce diagnostic error: a narrative review |journal=[[BMJ Quality & Safety]] |volume=21 |issue=7 |pages=535‚Äì557 |doi=10.1136/bmjqs-2011-000149 |pmid=22543420 |url=http://www.ajustnhs.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/cog-interventions-diag-error-graber-BMJ-QS-2012.pdf}}</ref>
Activities to promote reflection are now being incorporated into undergraduate, postgraduate and continuing medical education across a variety of health professions.<ref name="Mann">{{cite journal |last1=Mann |first1=Karen |last2=Gordon |first2=Jill |last3=MacLeod |first3=Anna |date=November 2007 |title=Reflection and reflective practice in health professions education: a systematic review |journal=Advances in Health Sciences Education |volume=14 |issue=4 |pages=595‚Äì621 |doi=10.1007/s10459-007-9090-2 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jill_Gordon/publication/5813985_Reflection_and_reflective_practice_in_health_professions_education_a_systematic_review/links/0c960517f54e18b6dd000000.pdf}}</ref> Professor of medical education Karen Mann and her colleagues found through a 2009 literature review that in practising professionals the process of reflection appears to include a number of different aspects, and practicing professionals vary in their tendency and ability to reflect. They noted that the evidence to support curricular interventions and innovations promoting reflective practice remains largely theoretical.<ref name="Mann"/>
Samantha Davies identified benefits as well as limitations to reflective practice:<ref>{{cite journal |last=Davies |first=Samantha |title=Embracing reflective practice |journal=Education for Primary Care |date=January 2012 |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=9‚Äì12 |pmid=22306139 |doi=10.1080/14739879.2012.11494064}}</ref>
Benefits to reflective practice include: * Increased learning from an experience or situation * Promotion of deep learning * Identification of personal and professional strengths and areas for improvement * Identification of educational needs * Acquisition of new knowledge and skills * Further understanding of own beliefs, attitudes and values * Encouragement of self-motivation and self-directed learning * Could act as a source of feedback * Possible improvements of personal and clinical confidence
Limitations to reflective practice include: * Not all practitioners may understand the reflective process * May feel uncomfortable challenging and evaluating own practice * Could be time consuming * May have confusion as to which situations/experiences to reflect upon * May not be adequate to resolve clinical problems<ref name="Price 2004"/>
===Environmental management and sustainability=== The use of reflective practice in [[environmental management]], combined with [[system monitoring]], is often called ''[[adaptive management]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Salafsky |first1=Nick Redford |last2=Margoluis |first2=Richard |last3=Redford |first3=Kent Hubbard |date=2001 |title=Adaptive management: a tool for conservation practitioners |location=Washington, DC |publisher=Biodiversity Support Program |oclc=48381963 |url=http://www.fosonline.org/resource/am-tool}}</ref> There is some criticism that traditional environmental management, which simply focuses on the problem at hand, fails to integrate into the decision making the wider systems within which an environment is situated.<ref name="Bryant 1998">{{cite journal |last1=Bryant |first1=Raymond L. |last2=Wilson |first2=Geo A. |title=Rethinking environmental management |journal=[[Progress in Human Geography]] |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=321‚Äì343 |date=June 1998 |doi=10.1191/030913298672031592}}</ref> While research and science must inform the process of environmental management, it is up to the practitioner to integrate those results within these wider systems.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fazey |first1=Ioan |last2=Fazey |first2=John A. |last3=Salisbury |first3=Janet G. |last4=Lindenmayer |first4=David B. |last5=Dovers |first5=Steve |title=The nature and role of experiential knowledge for environmental conservation |journal=Environmental Conservation |volume=33 |pages=1 |year=2006 |doi=10.1017/S037689290600275X |url=http://research-repository.st-andrews.ac.uk/bitstream/10023/1629/1/Fazey2006EnvironmentalConservation33ExperientialKnowledge.pdf}}</ref> In order to deal with this and to reaffirm the utility of environmental management, Bryant and Wilson propose that a "more reflective approach is required that seeks to rethink the basic premises of environmental management as a process".<ref name="Bryant 1998"/> This style of approach has been found to be successful in [[sustainable development]] projects where participants appreciated and enjoyed the educational aspect of utilising reflective practice throughout. However, the authors noted the challenges with melding the "circularity" of reflective practice theory with the "doing" of sustainability.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bell |first1=Simon |last2=Morse |first2=Stephen |title=Delivering sustainability therapy in sustainable development projects |journal=Journal of Environmental Management |volume=75 |issue=1 |pages=37‚Äì51 |year=2005 |pmid=15748802 |doi=10.1016/j.jenvman.2004.11.006 |url=http://oro.open.ac.uk/120/1/Deliv._Sus_Bell__Morse_JEM051.pdf}}</ref>
===Leadership positions=== Reflective practice provides a development opportunity for those in leadership positions. Managing a team of people requires a delicate balance between people skills and technical expertise, and success in this type of role does not come easily. Reflective practice provides leaders with an opportunity to critically review what has been successful in the past and where improvement can be made.
Reflective learning organizations have invested in [[coaching]] programs for their emerging and established leaders.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Avolio |first1=Bruce J. |last2=Avey |first2=James B. |last3=Quisenberry |first3=David |date=August 2010 |title=Estimating return on leadership development investment |journal=The Leadership Quarterly |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=633‚Äì644 |doi=10.1016/j.leaqua.2010.06.006 |url=http://uwtv.org/files/2013/01/roldleaqua650.pdf}}</ref> Leaders frequently engage in self-limiting behaviours because of their over-reliance on their preferred ways of reacting and responding.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Turesky |first1=Elizabeth Fisher |last2=Gallagher |first2=Dennis |title=Know thyself: coaching for leadership using Kolb's experiential learning theory |journal=The Coaching Psychologist |date=June 2011 |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=5‚Äì14 |url=http://people.usm.maine.edu/eturesky/Articles/KnowThyself.pdf}}</ref> Coaching can help support the establishment of new behaviours, as it encourages reflection, critical thinking and transformative learning. Adults have acquired a body of experience throughout their life, as well as habits of mind that define their world.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mezirow |first=Jack |authorlink=Jack Mezirow |title=Transformative learning: theory to practice |journal=New Directions for Adult and Continuing Education |date=Summer 1997 |volume=74 |pages=5‚Äì12 |doi=10.1002/ace.7401 |url=http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/~ntzcl1/literature/elearning/mezirow.pdf}}</ref> Coaching programs support the process of questioning and potentially rebuilding these pre-determined habits of mind. The goal is for leaders to maximize their professional potential, and in order to do this, there must be a process of critical reflection on current assumptions.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Helsing |first1=Deborah |last2=Howell |first2=Annie |last3=Kegan |first3=Robert |authorlink3=Robert Kegan |last4=Lahey |first4=Lisa Laskow |title=Putting the 'development' in professional development: understanding and overturning educational leaders' immunities to change |date=Fall 2008 |journal=[[Harvard Educational Review]] |volume=78 |issue=3 |pages=437‚Äì465 |url=http://www.bostonpublicschools.org/cms/lib07/MA01906464/Centricity/Domain/142/Kegan%20-%20Putting%20the%20Professional%20Development%20in%20PD.pdf |ref=harv |doi=10.17763/haer.78.3.888l759g1qm54660}}</ref>
===Other professions=== Reflective practice can help any individual to develop personally, and is useful for professions other than those discussed above. It allows professionals to continually update their skills and knowledge and consider new ways to interact with their colleagues. David Somerville and June Keeling suggested eight simple ways that professionals can practice more reflectively:<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Somerville |first1=David |last2=Keeling |first2=June |title=A practical approach to promote reflective practice within nursing |journal=[[Nursing Times]] |volume=100 |issue=12 |pages=42‚Äì45 |date=24 March 2004 |pmid=15067912 |url=http://www.nursingtimes.net/nursing-practice/specialisms/educators/a-practical-approach-to-promote-reflective-practice-within-nursing/204502.article}}</ref> # Seek feedback: Ask "Can you give me some feedback on what I did?" # Ask yourself "What have I learnt today?" and ask others "What have you learnt today?" # Value personal strengths: Identify positive accomplishments and areas for growth # View experiences objectively: Imagine the situation is on stage and you are in the audience # Empathize: Say out loud what you imagine the other person is experiencing # Keep a journal: Record your thoughts, feelings and future plans; look for emerging patterns # Plan for the future: Plan changes in behavior based on the patterns you identified # Create your own future: Combine the virtues of the dreamer, the realist, and the critic

'''Robots and Avatars''' was a programme of events and [[education]]al activities which explores how young people will work and play with new representational forms of virtual and physical life in 10‚Äì15 years time. It was produced by [[Body data space|body>data>space]] with support from [[National Endowment for Science Technology and the Arts|NESTA]].<ref>http://www.stanza.co.uk/emergentcity/?p=363</ref> between 2009 and 2012.
The project examined multi-identity evolutions of younger generations within the context of a world in which virtual and physical spaces are increasingly blended. A participatory web and events led programme with connected educational activities took taking place across 2010 and onwards, in the UK and internationally. The project included contributions by a diverse range of experts, professionals and specialists working with robots and avatars including Professor [[Noel Sharkey]] (Professor of Artificial Intelligence and Robotics and Professor of Public Engagement University of Sheffield), Pear Urishima (Apple), [[Ghislaine Boddington]] from body>data>space and [[Derek Richards]] from [[Hi8us]] South.<ref>http://www.apengine.org/2010/06/robots-and-avatars/</ref>
==Robots and Avatars Forum== Robots and Avatars launched in November 2009 with a Forum at NESTA, attended by an international group of 80 experts, professionals and young people in [[London]].
==Robots and Avatars Lunch Debates== Between June and November 2010 the programme hosted a series of Lunch Debates exploring Artificial Intelligence, Behaviour and Ethics, Health and Wellbeing and the Future Workplace with expert provocateurs and top level thinkers.
==The Overall Programme== The programme continued throughout 2010-2011 with educational events, an [[exhibition]], a [[website]], [[vodcast]]s with key experts and a book/[[DVD]].
==Themes== Robots and Avatars explored a wide range of themes including: * [[Robot]]s * [[Avatar (computing)|Avatar]]s * Future World of Work and Education * [[Identity (object-oriented programming)|Identity]] * [[Video game|Gaming]] * Gaming in Education * [[Artificial intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]] * [[Virtual world|Virtual Worlds]] * [[Performance]] * [[Telematics]] * [[New media art]] * [[Popular culture|Popular Culture]]
