{{tone|date=January 2015}} {{Youth rights sidebar}} A '''zero-tolerance policy in schools''' is a strict enforcement of regulations and bans against undesirable behaviors or possession of items. Public criticism against such policies have arisen due to their enforcement and the resulting (sometimes devastating) consequences when the behavior or possession was done in ignorance, by accident, or under [[extenuating circumstances]]. For example, a ban against guns resulting in a Rhode Island boy with a gun charm on a key chain being suspended. In schools, common zero-tolerance policies concern possession or use of illicit [[recreational drug use|drugs]] or [[weapon]]s. Students, and sometimes staff, parents, and other visitors, who possess a banned item for any reason are always (if the policy is followed) to be punished.
In the United States and Canada, [[Zero tolerance|zero-tolerance]] policies have been adopted in various schools and other education venues. Zero-tolerance policies in the United States became widespread in 1994, after federal legislation required states to expel any student who brought a firearm to school for one year, or lose all federal funding.<ref name=Cauchon>{{cite web |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/educate/ednews3.htm |title=Zero-tolerance policies lack flexibility |work=usatoday.com}}</ref>
These policies are promoted as preventing [[drug abuse]] and [[violence in schools]]. Critics say zero tolerance in schools have resulted in punishments which have been criticised as egregiously unfair against students and teachers, especially in schools with poorly written policies. Consequently, critics describe these policies as '''zero-logic policies''' because they treat juveniles the way that adults would be treated<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.delawareliberal.net/2009/10/06/zero-tolerance-is-zero-intelligence/ |title=Zero Tolerance is Zero Intelligence |date=6 October 2009 |publisher=Delaware Liberal}}</ref> ‚Äî or more harshly, given that children are seldom granted full permission to speak up in their own defense to adults with authority over them. Many people have been critical of zero tolerance policies, claiming that they are overly draconian, provide little if any benefit to anyone, contribute to overcrowding of the [[criminal justice system]], and/or disproportionately target blacks and Latinos.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/8/19/zero-tolerance-school.html |title=LA schools to end zero-tolerance policies and criminalization of students |work=aljazeera.com}}</ref>
==Research== There is no credible evidence that zero tolerance reduces violence or drug abuse by students.<ref name=skiba2000/> Furthermore, school [[suspension (punishment)|suspension]] and [[expulsion (education)|expulsion]] result in a number of negative outcomes for both schools and students.<ref name="skiba2000">Russell J. Skiba [https://web.archive.org/web/20140824031650/http://www.indiana.edu/%7Esafeschl/ztze.pdf Zero Tolerance, Zero Evidence: An Analysis of School Disciplinary Practice] Policy Research Report #SRS2 August, 2000</ref> The [[American Bar Association]] finds that the evidence indicates that minority children are the most likely to suffer the negative consequences of zero tolerance policies. Analysis of the suspension rate of students show that black females and other racial minorities are suspended at a greater rate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://civilrightsproject.ucla.edu/resources/projects/center-for-civil-rights-remedies/school-to-prison-folder/federal-reports/are-we-closing-the-school-discipline-gap/AreWeClosingTheSchoolDisciplineGap_FINAL221.pdf |title=ARE WE CLOSING THE SCHOOL DISCIPLINE GAP? |work=UCLA C E N T E R F O R C I V I L R I G H T S R E M E D I E S |date=Feb 2015}}</ref> The [[American Psychological Association]] concluded that the available evidence does not support the use of zero tolerance policies as defined and implemented, that there is a clear need to modify such policies, and that the policies create a number of unintended negative consequences,<ref>Are Zero Tolerance Policies Effective in the Schools? An evidentiary review and recommendations. [http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/amp/63/9/ ''American Psychologist,'' December 2008.]</ref><ref>[http://everydaypsychology.com/2009/03/zero-tolerance-policies-no-substitute.html Zero Tolerance Policies: no substitute for good judgment] Summary of the APA Task Force Report at everydaypsychology.com</ref> including making schools "less safe".<ref name=Nuckols />
In 2014, a study of [[school discipline]] figures was conducted. It was found that suspensions and expulsions as a result of zero tolerance policies have not reduced school disruptions. The study's author stated that "zero tolerance approaches to school discipline are not the best way to create a safe climate for learning".<ref name=skiba2014>Skiba, R. J. (2014). [https://reclaimingjournal.com/sites/default/files/journal-article-pdfs/22_4_Skiba.pdf The Failure of Zero Tolerance. Reclaiming Children & Youth] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626103635/https://reclaimingjournal.com/sites/default/files/journal-article-pdfs/22_4_Skiba.pdf |date=June 26, 2015 }}, 22(4), 27-33.</ref> Zero tolerance policies are sometimes viewed as a quick fix solution for student problems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ernweb.com/educational-research-articles/zero-tolerance-still-in-use-despite-lack-of-evidence/ |title=Zero-tolerance still in use despite lack of evidence |work=Educational Research Newsletters & Webinars}}</ref><ref>Martinez, S. (2009). A system gone berserk: How are zero-tolerance policies really affecting schools? Preventing School Failure,53(3), 153-157.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nau.edu/uploadedFiles/Academic/COE/About/Projects/From%20Zero%20Tolerance%20to%20Early%20Intervention.pdf |title=From Zero Tolerance to Early Intervention: The Evolution of School Anti-bullying Policy |author=Ginette D. Roberge |year=2012}}</ref> While this seems like a simple action-reaction type of situation, it often leaves out the mitigating circumstances that are often the important details in student incidents. Even civilian judges consider mitigating circumstances before passing judgement or sentencing. If zero tolerance policies were applied in adult courtroom scenarios, they would be fundamentally unjust and unconstitutional due to neglecting the laws involving due process, along with cruel and unusual punishments.
==History== The label of zero tolerance began with the [[Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994]], when Congress authorized public-school funding subject to the adoption of zero-tolerance policies.<ref>{{cite journal |publisher=Pace Law Review |volume=20 |issue=1 |date=1999 |title=The Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994: Zero Tolerance Takes Aim at Procedural Due Process |author=Kathleen M. Cerrone |url=http://digitalcommons.pace.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1265&context=plr}}</ref> Similar policies of intolerance coupled with expulsions for less serious behaviors than bringing a weapon to school had long been a part of private, and particularly religious, schools. The use of zero-tolerance policies in secular, public schools increased dramatically after the [[Columbine High School massacre]], with principals declaring that safety concerns made them want zero tolerance for weapons. These have led to a large number of disproportionate responses to minor, or technical transgressions, many of which have attracted the attention of the international media. These cases include students being suspended or expelled for such offenses as possession of [[ibuprofen]] or [[Midol]] (both legal, non-prescription drugs commonly used to treat [[Dysmenorrhea|menstrual cramps]] and [[headache]]s) with permission of the students' parents, keeping [[pocket knife|pocketknives]] (small utility knife) in cars, and carrying sharp tools outside of a woodshop classroom (where they are often required materials). In Seal v. Morgan, a student was expelled for having a knife in his car on school property, despite his protestations that he was unaware of the knife's presence.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Henault|first1=Cherry|title=Zero Tolerance in Schools|journal=Journal of Law & Education|date=2001|volume=30|issue=3|pages=547‚Äì53}}</ref> In some jurisdictions, zero-tolerance policies have come into conflict with freedom of religion rules already in place allowing students to carry, for example, [[kirpan]]s.
In the [[kids for cash scandal|"kids for cash" scandal]], judge [[Mark Ciavarella]], who promoted a platform of zero tolerance, received kickbacks for constructing a private prison that housed juvenile offenders, and then proceeded to fill the prison by sentencing children to extended stays in juvenile detention for offenses as minimal as mocking a [[Principal (academia)|principal]] on [[Myspace]], scuffles in hallways, trespassing in a vacant building, and shoplifting [[DVD]]s from [[Wal-Mart]]. Critics of zero-tolerance policies argue that harsh punishments for minor offenses are normalized. The documentary ''Kids for Cash'' interviews experts on adolescent behavior, who argue that the zero tolerance model has become a dominant approach to policing juvenile offenses after the Columbine shooting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jjie.org/a-plot-with-a-scandal-a-close-look-at-the-kids-for-cash-documentary/ |title=A Plot with a Scandal: A Closer Look at ‚ÄòKids for Cash‚Äô Documentary |first=Daryl|last=Khan |date=10 February 2014 |work=Juvenile Justice Information Exchange}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemaparadiso.co.uk/blog/film-reviews/kids-for-cash-review/ |title=Kids for Cash Review |first=Mark|last=McPherson |date=20 March 2015 |work=Cinema Paradiso Blog}}</ref>
In [[New York City]], [[Carmen Fari√±a]], head of the [[New York City Department of Education]], restricted school suspension by principals in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/14/nyregion/suspension-rules-altered-in-new-york-citys-revision-of-school-discipline-code.html?_r=0 |title=Suspension Rules Altered in New York City‚Äôs Revision of School Discipline Code |work=New York Times |date=13 Feb 2015}}</ref> The [[Los Angeles Unified School District|Los Angeles Unified]] school board, responsible for educating 700,000 students, voted in 2013 to ban suspensions for "willful defiance", which had mostly been used against students from racial minorities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/may/14/local/la-me-lausd-suspension-20130515 |title=L.A. Unified bans suspension for 'willful defiance' |work=Los Angeles Times |date=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2015/03/zeroing-out-zero-tolerance/388003/ |title=Zeroing out Zero Tolerance |first=Carly|last=Berwick |date=17 May 2015 |work=The Atlantic}}</ref> A year later, the same school district decided to [[Decriminalization|decriminalize]] school discipline so that minor offenses would be referred to school staff rather than prosecuted -- the previous approach had resulted in black students being six times more likely to be arrested or given a ticket than white students.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Old school rap: LA pupils face teacher for minor crimes|last=|first=|date=22 August 2014|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|page=26|access-date=|via=}}</ref> The district saw suspensions drop by 53%, and graduation rates rise by 12%.<ref name=":0" />
===Media attention=== Media attention has proven embarrassing to school officials, resulting in changes to state laws as well as to local school policies. One school board member gave this reason for changes his district made to their rigid policy: "We are doing this because we got egg on our face."<ref name=Urbina>{{cite news |title=After Uproar on Suspension, District Will Rewrite Rules |author=Urbina, Ian |date=13 October 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/14/education/14discipline.html}}</ref>
* A student at [[Sandusky High School]] in [[Sandusky, Ohio]], was suspended for 90 days and failed, after school authorities searched him for drugs in September 1999, and found a broken pocketknife. He had used the knife to clean his [[Cleat (shoe)|golfing cleat]]s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Petras |first1=Kathryn |last2=Petras |first2=Ross |title=Unusually Stupid Americans (A compendium of all American Stupidity) |year=2003 |publisher=Villard Books |location=New York |isbn=0-9658068-7-1 |pages=15‚Äì16}}</ref> * The [[Christina School District]] in [[Newark, Delaware]], has experienced multiple highly publicized cases of zero tolerance: ** After bringing a [[Cub Scouting (Boy Scouts of America)|Cub Scout]]s dinner knife to school to eat his lunch, a six-year-old boy was ordered to attend an [[alternative school]] for students with behavioral problems for nine weeks.<ref name=Urbina/> After a media uproar, the school board voted unanimously to reduce punishments for kindergartners and first-graders who take weapons to school to a 3-5 day mandatory suspension,<ref name=Nuckols>{{cite news|author=Nuckols, Ben |title=Delaware board likely to tweak zero-tolerance rule |agency=Associated Press |date=13 October 2009 |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091013/ap_on_re_us/us_zero_tolerance_boy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016165454/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091013/ap_on_re_us/us_zero_tolerance_boy |archivedate=October 16, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=CSD>{{cite news|author=Nuckols, Ben |agency=Associated Press |date=14 October 2009 |title=Delaware 1st grader has 45-day suspension lifted |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017070809/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091014/ap_on_re_us/us_zero_tolerance_boy |archivedate=October 17, 2009 }}</ref> retaining the original definition of "weapons".<ref>{{cite press release |title=Christina Board Will Consider Amendment to Student Code of Conduct for Youngest Students |date=13 October 2009 |publisher=Christina School District |url=http://www.christina.k12.de.us/News/2009/1013_CodeOfConduct.htm |accessdate=2009-10-14}}</ref> **A third-grader was expelled for a year because her grandmother sent a birthday cake, and a knife for cutting the cake, to school. The teacher used the knife to cut the cake, and then reported her to the authorities as having a dangerous weapon. The expulsion was overturned and led to a state law that gave districts the ability to, "on a case-by-case basis, modify the terms of the expulsion."<ref name=NYT>{{cite news |title=It‚Äôs a Fork, It‚Äôs a Spoon, It‚Äôs a ... Weapon? |author=Urbina, Ian |date=12 October 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/12/education/12discipline.html}}</ref> ** Other cases include a straight-A student who was ordered to attend "reform school" after a classmate dropped a pocket knife in his lap,<ref name=NYT /> and in 2007, when a girl was expelled for using a [[utility knife]] to cut paper for a project.<ref name=NYT /> * Earlier in 2009, an [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]] in [[New York (state)|New York]] was suspended for 20 days for having an [[Survival kit|emergency supply kit]] in his car that included a pocket knife.<ref>{{cite web | last=Lott | first=Maxim | title=New York Eagle Scout Suspended From School for 20 Days for Keeping Pocketknife in Car | website=Fox News | date=2009-10-13 | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2009/10/13/new-york-eagle-scout-suspended-from-school-for-20-days-for-keeping-pocketknife.html | accessdate=2015-09-22}}</ref> * A kindergartner in [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]], was suspended in March 2010 for making a [[finger gun]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2010/03/ionia_kindergartener_suspended.html |title=Ionia kindergartner suspended for making gun with hand |last=McVicar |first=Brian |date=March 4, 2010 |work=[[The Grand Rapids Press]] |publisher=[[Booth Newspapers]] |accessdate=11 August 2010 |location=Ionia}}</ref> * Another kindergartner, in [[Pennsylvania]], was suspended for 10 days in January 2013 for referring to "shooting" a friend with a [[Hello Kitty]] bubble making gun.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/01/19/pennsylvania-girl-5-suspended-for-threatening-to-shoot-girl-with-pink-toy-gun/ |title=Pennsylvania girl, 5, suspended for threatening to shoot girl with pink toy gun that blows soapy bubbles |last=DeMarche |first=Edmund |date=19 January 2013 |work=[[FoxNews]]}}</ref> The suspension was reduced to two days after the parent met with school officials. * A second grader in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], was suspended in March 2013 for biting a [[Pop-Tart]] into the shape of a mountain, which school officials mistook for a gun.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2287085/Pastry-gun-suspension-Baltimore-school-suspends-Josh-Welch-7-shaping-breakfast-pastry-gun.html |location=London |work=Daily Mail |title=School suspends 7-year-old for shaping breakfast pastry into 'shape of a gun' |date=March 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://now.msn.com/josh-welch-7-suspended-for-shaping-pastry-into-gun-shape |title=Josh Welch 7, Suspended For Shaping Pastry Into Gun Shape |publisher=MSN News |date= |accessdate=June 25, 2014}}</ref> * 6-year-old [[Suspension of Hunter Yelton|Hunter Yelton]] in [[Colorado]] was suspended in 2013 for alleged repeated sexual harassment of a 6-year-old schoolmate, a charge the boy's family disputed. Following widespread negative media coverage and public disapproval, the school agreed to downgrade the suspension cause to "misconduct". * [[Ahmed Mohamed (student)|A freshman]] at [[MacArthur High School (Irving, Texas)|MacArthur High School]] in [[Irving, Texas]], was suspended for a week in September 2015 after he put a digital [[alarm clock]] in a pencil box, and took it to his school to show a teacher. When the device beeped while in one class, the student was suspended and detained on suspicion of creating a hoax bomb.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/northwest-dallas-county/headlines/20150915-irving-ninth-grader-arrested-after-taking-homemade-clock-to-school.ece|title=Irving 9th-grader arrested after taking homemade clock to school: 'So you tried to make a bomb?'|publisher=The Dallas Morning News|first=Avi|last=Selk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150916031234/http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/northwest-dallas-county/headlines/20150915-irving-ninth-grader-arrested-after-taking-homemade-clock-to-school.ece|date=September 15, 2015|archivedate=September 16, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=September 20, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/19/us/irving-police-chief-defends-response-to-ahmed-mohameds-clock.html?src=mv&_r=0 | title=Irving Police Chief Defends Response to Ahmed Mohamed‚Äôs Clock | publisher=NY Times | accessdate=September 20, 2015}}</ref> * In the [[Escondido school knives case]], Brian Capalletti and another student in [[San Diego]] were suspended from school for between 2 and 3 weeks and faced criminal charges and possible expulsion after knives were found in their vehicles parked outside their [[Escondido, California|Escondido]] high school.
==Promotion== Proponents of punishment- and exclusion-based philosophy of school discipline policies claim that such policies are required to create an appropriate environment for learning.<ref name=skiba2014/><ref name=Noguera1995>Noguera, Pedro A. [http://youthjusticenc.org/download/education-justice/prevention-intervention-alternatives/Preventing%20and%20Producing%20Violence:%20A%20Critical%20Analysis%20of%20Responses%20to%20School%20Violence.pdf Preventing and Producing Violence: A Critical Analysis of Responses to School Violence] ''Harvard Educational Review'', Summer 1995, pp. 189‚Äì212.</ref> This rests on the assumption that strong enforcement can act as a [[Deterrence (psychology)|psychological deterrent]] to other potentially disruptive students.<ref name=skiba2014/>
The policy assumption is that inflexibility is a deterrent because, no matter how or why the rule was broken, the fact that the rule was broken is the basis for the imposition of the penalty. This is intended as a [[behavior modification]] strategy: since those at risk know that it may operate unfairly, they may be induced to take even unreasonable steps to avoid breaking the rule. This is a standard policy in rule- and law-based systems around the world on "offenses" as minor as traffic violations to major health and safety legislation for the protection of employees and the environment.<ref>Ghezzi, Patti. "Zero tolerance for zero tolerance" ''Atlanta Constitution'', March 20, 2006.</ref>
Disciplinarian parents view zero-tolerance policies as a tool to fight corruption.<ref>Takyi-Boadu, Charles. "On Zero-Tolerance Corruption not Province of Politicians." ''The Ghanaian Chronicle'', March 16, 2006.</ref> Under this argument, if subjective judgment is not allowed, most attempts by the authority person to encourage bribes or other favors in exchange for leniency are clearly visible.
==Criticism== Critics of zero-tolerance policies in schools say they are part of a [[United States school-to-prison link|school-to-prison pipeline]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbar.org/publications/gpsolo_ereport/2014/june_2014/the_emergence_of_the_school-to-prison_pipeline.html|title=The Emergence of the School-to-Prison Pipeline - Solo, Small Firm and General Practice Division|website=www.americanbar.org|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref> that over-polices children with behavioural problems, treating their problems as criminal justice issues rather than educational and behavioural problems. Students that may previously have been given short school suspensions before the implementation of policies are now sent to juvenile courts.<ref name="ScottSteinberg2009">{{cite book |author1=Elizabeth S Scott |author2=Laurence D Steinberg |title=Rethinking Juvenile Justice |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QEkbMyBLJXIC |date=30 June 2009 |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-04336-7 |page=5}}</ref>
Critics of zero-tolerance policies frequently refer to cases where minor offenses have resulted in severe punishments. Typical examples include the honor-roll student being expelled from school under a "no weapons" policy while in possession of [[nail clipper]]s,<ref>[http://www.abanet.org/crimjust/juvjus/zerotolreport.html Final Report, Bi Partisan Working Group on Youth Violence] 106th Congress, February 1996 Zero Tolerance Policy Report, American Bar Association</ref> or for possessing "drugs" like [[cough drop]]s and dental [[mouthwash]] or "weapons" like [[rubber band]]s.<ref name=Cauchon/>
A related criticism is that zero-tolerance policies make schools feel like a [[jail]] or a [[prison]]. Furthermore zero-tolerance policies have been struck down by U.S. courts<ref>"Pensacola honor students win zero tolerance drug ruling" article of the AP/Bradenton Herald, Sept. 8, 2002 at [http://www.overlawyered.com/archives/02/sept3.html#0930b Overlawyered.com archives Sept. 2002 pt. III]</ref> and by departments of education.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/freespeech/youth/28109prs20070119.html Rhode Island Officials Rule School Can't Censor Teen's Yearbook Photo] (1/19/2007)</ref>
Another criticism is that the zero-tolerance policies have actually caused schools to [[turn a blind eye]] to bullying, resulting in them refusing to solve individual cases in an attempt to make their image look better. The zero-tolerance policy also punishes both the attacker and the defender in a fight, even when the attacker was the one who started the fight unprovoked.
A particularly dismaying hypothesis about zero tolerance policies is that they may actually discourage some people from reporting criminal and illegal behavior, for fear of losing relationships, and for many other reasons. That is, ironically, zero tolerance policies may be ineffective in the very purpose for which they were originally designed.<ref>Rowe, Mary and Bendersky, Corinne, "Workplace Justice, Zero Tolerance and Zero Barriers: Getting People to Come Forward in Conflict Management Systems," in Negotiations and Change, From the Workplace to Society, Thomas Kochan and Richard Locke (editors), Cornell University Press, 2002</ref>
As schools develop responses to [[online bullying]], schools that have overly harsh approaches to zero tolerance policies may increasingly police speech of students in their own time, that would normally be protected by [[free speech]] laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.americanbar.org/litigation/committees/childrights/content/articles/fall2012-0912-zero-tolerance-online-bullying-free-speech.html|title=Zero Tolerance for Online Bullying Can Hamper Free Speech - Children's Rights Litigation - ABA Section of Litigation|website=apps.americanbar.org|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
The [[American Bar Association]] opposes "zero tolerance policies that mandate either expulsion or referral of students to juvenile or criminal court, without regard to the circumstances or nature of the offense or the students{{sic}} history."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbar.org/groups/child_law/tools_to_use/attorneys/school_disciplinezerotolerancepolicies.html|title=School Discipline "Zero Tolerance" Policies - Center on Children and the Law|website=www.americanbar.org|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
Critics of zero tolerance policies also argue that the large numbers of students who are suspended and expelled from school experience negative effects which can prohibit them from finishing high school. Students who experience suspension, expulsion and arrests pay higher psychological and social costs: such as depression, suicidal thoughts, academic failure, and run the risk of being incarcerated as adults. In a study by Forrest et. al., (2000), psychologists identified that a third of youths in juvenile detention centers were diagnosed with depression shortly after being incarcerated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Scogin|first=Forrest|last2=Welsh|first2=Douglas|last3=Hanson|first3=Ashley|last4=Stump|first4=Jamie|last5=Coates|first5=Adriana|date=2005-09-01|title=Evidence-Based Psychotherapies for Depression in Older Adults|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1093/clipsy.bpi033/abstract|journal=Clinical Psychology: Science and Practice|language=en|volume=12|issue=3|pages=222‚Äì237|doi=10.1093/clipsy.bpi033|issn=1468-2850}}</ref> In addition to being diagnosed with depression many youths found themselves having suicidal thoughts (Gnau et. al. 1997).<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Mace D, Rohde P, Gnau V |date=1997|title=Psychological patterns of depression and suicidal behavior of adolescents in a juvenile detention facility.|url=|journal=Journal for Juvenile Justice and Detention Services.|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
Research found that Black, Latino, and White adults with low educational attainment risked a higher propensity of being incarcerated in their lifetime (Pettit & Western 2010).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Western|first=Bruce|last2=Pettit|first2=Becky|title=Incarceration & social inequality|url=http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/pdf/10.1162/DAED_a_00019|journal=Daedalus|volume=139|issue=3|pages=8‚Äì19|doi=10.1162/daed_a_00019}}</ref> In the same study they found that the incarceration rate in 2008 rose to 37% since the 1980‚Äôs. This showed that incarceration rates of people with low levels of education were continuing to rise and that students were not completing their high school requirements.
According to kidsdata.org for the year 2012, 21,638 students were suspended and 592 students were expelled from San Diego County schools. A total of 10.1% of students did not complete their high school diploma.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kidsdata.org|title=Kidsdata: Data and Resources about the Health of Children|website=Kidsdata.org|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
Despite a decrease in juvenile arrest, suspensions, expulsions, and drop out rates, many still argue that these disciplinary policies have helped contribute to students not completing their high school curriculum. Schools are struggling to keep students within the walls of the educational system rather than the walls of a juvenile detention center.
==Escondido school knives case== The '''Escondido school knives case''' is a collection of school suspensions, possible expulsions, and protests surrounding knives that were found in the cars of two students at [[San Pasqual High School (Escondido, California)|San Pasqual High School]] in [[Escondido, California|Escondido]], [[California]].
===Discovery and arrests=== Brandon Cappaletti, an 18-year-old student at the school, had been on a fishing trip in early January, 2016. He says he had used the knives to cut line and would have used them to prepare fish. After the fishing trip, he left the knives in his truck. Another 16-year-old student had a [[pocket knife]] in his [[glove compartment]].<ref name=reason_zero>{{cite news|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/02/12/zero-tolerance-2-teens-face-expulsion-ja|title=Zero Tolerance: 2 Teens Face Expulsion, Jail for Fishing Knives, Advil in Their Cars|author=Soave, Robby}}</ref>
On January 27, police dogs were sniffing vehicles in the school's parking lot. Each student had [[Advil]] in the truck. In each case, the dogs alerted on the Advil. Cappaletti was called out of class to unlock the truck. The police found the Advil and the knives. In the case of the 16-year-old, the alert also which led to the police finding the pocket knife.<ref name=reason_zero/>
Both boys were [[arrested]]. Cappaletti was later released to his mother. The 16-year-old's case was referred to the California's [[diversion program|juvenile diversion program]]. Both boys have been charged with a [[misdemeanor]] for having a knife on school property with a blade longer than two-and-a-half [[inch]]es. Both were also immediately suspended from classes.<ref name=reason_zero/> A hearing on Feb. 25 will decide whether or not they will be expelled.
===Impact and protests=== Cappaletti has already joined the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marines Corps]]. If convicted of the misdemeanor, he might not be able to remain. His mother Amy Cappelletti said that ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the most patriotic student. He never gets into trouble. These weren‚Äôt Crocodile Dundee knives.‚Äù<ref name=uniontribune_zero_tolerance>{{cite news|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2016/feb/09/zero-tolerance-escondido-knife-expulsion/#sthash.GsHMyUcO.dpuf|title=Forgotten knives meet zero tolerance|author=Miao, Pat|work=[[San Diego Union Tribune]]|date=9 February 2016}}</ref> At a School Board meeting on February 9, 2016, hundreds of people asked the Board not to expel the two students. Tony Coreley, the high school's [[Coach (American football)|football coach]] said that ‚ÄúThere are rules and laws that the district has to follow, but this (situation) is unfortunate.‚Äù<ref name=uniontribune_zero_tolerance/>
School District spokeswoman Karyl O‚ÄôBrien said that the situation was unfortunate, but under California's zero-tolerance policy, there were rules the school had to follow.
===Resolution=== On February 11, 2016, the [[Superintendent (education)|Superintendent]] of the [[Escondido Union School District]] stated that the students would not be expelled, and that they were expected to be allowed to return to school the following week.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Escondido-San-Pasqual-High-School-Student-Knives-Sam-Serrato-Brandon-Cappelletti-368639191.html|title=San Pasqual High School Students Found With Knives Will Not be Expelled|author=Garske, Monica}}</ref> As of February 13, the misdemeanor charges remain unresolved.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbs8.com/story/31208965/too-harsh-students-face-expulsion-and-misdemeanors|title=No expulsion, students still face misdemeanors|work=[[NBC San Diego]]|date=13 February 2015}}</ref>
